subject: Ethics
title: Induced Pluripotent Stem Cells
description: A short lesson to help you apply Induced Pluripotent Stem Cells.

hook.text: What if you could turn a skin cell back into an embryonic-like stem cell? No embryo needed.

buildup.text: In 2006, Shinya Yamanaka reprogrammed adult mouse cells into pluripotent stem cells using four genes.

discovery.text: iPSCs can become almost any cell typeâ€”heart, nerve, liverâ€”without destroying a single embryo.

twist.text: This didn't end the debate. iPSCs could theoretically create sperm, eggs, even embryo-like structures.

climax.text: Yamanaka won the Nobel Prize. The technology sidesteps one ethical wall but builds new ones.

punchline.text: Solving one dilemma often just reveals the next one.

quiz.question: Why were induced pluripotent stem cells considered an ethical breakthrough?
options: They avoid the need to destroy embryos to obtain pluripotent cells
They are cheaper to produce than embryonic stem cells
They work better in clinical treatments than any other cell type
